page.title: 05STATISTICS OF THE RESERVOIRS
page.content: There are three reservoirs which form one large water catchment. The heighest one is Wessenden Old, built in 1839 and 299.6m. above sea level. Then when it was necessary to collect more water another dam was built in 1903 to form Blakeley Reservoir. This is 258.2m. above sea level. Finally to complete the system Butterley, 234.4m. above sea level, was formed in 1907 below the other two. Butterley is the largest with a surface area of 15 hectares, a capacity of 1,773 thousand cubic metres(tcm) and a depth of 28.3m. Blakeley is the smallest with 108tcm. a surface area of 3 hectares and a depth of 18.9m. Wessenden with a depth of 14.9m. is not as deep as Blakeley but is larger at 391tcm. and a surface area of 7 hectares.
